msgs.text: Question: How can we reach a price of $100,000,000 per coin when the market cap necessary for that seems unreachable based on the amount of wealth in the world? Is the market cap of Bitcoin misleading? How does illiquid supply effect the market cap of Bitcoin? Can you recall/link/speak on the Bank of America study that said something like $1 invested in BTC means the market cap jumps by $100?

Thread containing notes, articles and videos on the subject including those from Dylan, Willy Woo and Invest Answers. I'm curious to hear everyone's thoughts after you digest some of this:
https://twitter.com/LukeMikic21/status/1435462931831922694?s=20

I found an article on the Bank of America study. "BoFA argues, with just $93 million of net inflows triggering a 1% price increase, a level that requires around $1.86 billon for a corresponding move in gold." 
https://www.thestreet.com/investing/bitcoin-is-dirty-slow-volatile-and-impractical-bofa-report

Apparently someone did some maths on top of those numbers to find that there is 118x multiplayer from $ invested to market cap. $1 invested raises the market cap by $118. I'm trying to figure this out myself but not sure
Apparently that someone was British HODL who just also replied to one of my tweets adding this info

The MC is determined by taking the LAST price a coin was sold at and multiplying that by the amount of coins in circulation. So as money flows into BTC, the price rises, meaning the scale on the MC rises more than 1:1.
